title: Widespread heatwave likely to linger into the New Year. Here's how to stay safe amid soaring temperatures
text:
Locals try to cool off in outback town Boulia, as the mercury heads towards 45C. (Supplied: Zacahary Hart)
Scorching temperatures are hitting communities across the east coast of Australia with even hotter conditions and severe storms expected later on Friday and over the weekend.
Much of northern Australia is sweltering through heatwave conditions set to peak in some areas on Saturday and endure into the new year.
On Queensland’s coast, many residents will ring in 2024 displaced from ruined homes amid a colossal clean-up in the aftermath of this week’s severe storms in the south-east and ex-tropical cyclone Jasper.
Bureau of Meteorology data showed many towns across Queensland sweltering through near-40-degree Celsius heat at 10am on Friday, with hotter temperatures expected over the weekend for some communities.
On the coast, Brisbane had reached 37.5C at 1:00pm on Friday while the Gold Coast was expecting to hit 33C, but a seabreeze kept temperatures closer to 30C.
Further inland, the mercury rose, with Emerald reaching 36.9C at 1.54pm and Roma topping out at 39.2C at 1.38pm..
In the outback, temperatures were tipped to skyrocket to 47C in Birdsville.
Longreach will be in record-breaking territory if it reaches more than 47C as expected over the weekend —beating the previous maximum temperature of 47.3 from January, 1990.
“This weekend, a number of locations will reach above 40C, and into the mid-to-high 40s,” said the BOM’s Claire Yeo.
West and central Queensland as well as the Top End were set to suffer some of the most extreme heat with Marble Bar in Western Australia expecting the hottest temperature in the country — 48C on Saturday, the Bureau said.
Health warnings for the vulnerable Queensland Ambulance Service officer Brad Hardy said hospitals around the state were bracing for an uptick in heat-related illnesses.
He urged those susceptible to the heat — the elderly, children and pregnant women — to be aware of signs of heat stress.
“As soon as you start sweating you’re losing fluids and can rapidly become dehydrated if you’re in these really hot temperatures,” Superintendent Hardy said.
“You can become restless, flushed in the skin to the point where you stop sweating.
“That’s extremely dangerous and can be fatal … your organs can start to shut down to keep your brain working and that damage can be immense and irreversible.”
For more tips on how to stay safe in a heatwave visit the ABC Emergency website here.
Residents get creative to keep cool Tried and tested methods like keeping ice blocks handy, hauling out the paddle pool, buckets of water and cool drinks were the go-to for residents trying to stay cool.
Tradesmen in the outback town of Cloncurry used their water trucks to spray neighbours cooling off in backyards and the Gold Coast council offered free entry to the local pools.
Fire stations at Mount Tamborine opened their doors to people who needed an air-conditioned place to cool down.
In Birdsville, ranger Don Rowlands said locals had a few tricks for dealing with the hottest time of the year.
“You start your day early and by 10am, everyone retires to the lounge room and puts on a good movie in the air-conditioning,” he said.
“The kids run down to the river early in the morning and come home late at night … they’re just swimming all day.”
Nicole Liu, in the outback town of Mount Isa, where temperatures were set to reach 45C over the weekend, said she had to bring her kids to the pool early to beat the stifling heat.
“You have to come early otherwise you just can’t enjoy it. We’re here at 9.30am and it already feels like you’re standing in an oven,” she said.
As an outback local, Ms Liu said residents expected temperatures to be high this time of year, but that the heat “still hits you pretty hard”.
“We hang around the pool and keep ice blocks handy, crank the aircon…I’m not looking forward to my electricity bill,” she said.
Iced coffees were in hot demand at Nambour cafe Small Change Espresso this morning, with the town expected to reach 37C.
Worker Alex Atkins said he had noticed fewer customers opting to dine in.
“A lot more iced coffees than usual,” he said.
“Because of the heat people are getting takeaways because it’s too hot to sit in here.”
He said the store had several large fans running but they were doing little to bring the temperature down.
“We’ve stocked our fridges with cold water, people are asking for water as soon as they walk in,” he said.
“It was already hot as soon as we got here and we’ve got fans to work with.”
Helping animals beat the heat Grazier Josie Angus from the central Queensland community of Clermont was helping her cattle get through 39C temperatures.
She said her stock was northern bred and used to high temperatures, but it was still difficult to keep them cool.
“It’s always an extra challenge,” Ms Angus said.
“All of our cattle are on heat-load rations and we cool down their ration a bit just to make sure that they’re going to cope with it.”
The RSPCA recommends multiple sources of water in shady spots for pets.
Cooling matts, paddle pools and frozen treats are another way to help your furry friend beat the heat.
“Never leave your dog tied up in the yard or in a hot car during a heatwave,” the RSPCA website warns.
Rain on the way but heat to endure While the hottest day for the northern half of Australia will be Saturday, temperatures will not drop by much over the coming week, the BOM says.
Storms and rain were predicted for parts of the central west and east coast over the weekend while a chance of rain was forecast for western and north-west Queensland mid-to-late next week.
While the rain would bring some reprieve, it would not do much to ease the heat, Ms Yeo said.
“Central and western Queensland maximum temperatures unfortunately do not fall below 40 degrees for the remainder of the week.”
Superintendent Hardy urged all those in heat-affected areas to take it easy.
“Temperatures are not just a few degrees above average, they’re up to many degrees above average,” he said.
“Stay cool and take the risk of heat stress very seriously.”
